bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to J.F. Siler, February 4, 1948

div1.p: Truby discusses the location of the room where Walter Reed died. Truby requested and received floor plans from the commanding officer of Washington Barracks, where Reed died. However, they do not conform with his memory. Truby feels that he cannot make any positive statement as to the exact location of the room unless they unearth something to solve this discrepancy.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to J.F. Siler, February 4, 1948
div1.opener:
copy
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, Calif.
February 4, 1948
Col. J. F. Siler, Ret'd.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Siler:
div1.p:
Dr. Hench has sent me copies of his letters to you about the room at the
old General Hospital at Washington Barracks in which Major Walter Reed died.
So, under separate cover, I am sending you the floor plans (2nd floor) which
the Commanding Officer sent at my request. Dr. Hench is to be in Washington
about the middle of this month and I feel sure he will promptly get in touch
with you and will want to see this letter and the plans.

The plans are not dated and certainly do not conform to my memory of the
second floor as it was when Major Reed died in 1902. He was in a private
room, about 12 X 15 feet, and but one bed. No such small private room exists
in the plans we have. The entrance of Reed's room was near the end of the
hallway as you go back towards the west from the landing at the top of the
stairs. (See Dr. Hench's sketch of the rooms as they now exist.)

As stated above, there is no small private room in the plans of the entire
second floor. I am quite confident that General Kean will remember that
Major Reed was in a small private room on the second floor of the old General
Hospital, now Building 56B. Personally, I am certain of those points. Both
Kean and I also know that Reed died in that building.

Only one explanation occurs to me - that as Major Borden's surgical activities
increased, the greater part of the second floor was changed and larger rooms
(spare wards) were made so that more patients could be accomodated in the
small building. Now, if those changes were made late in 1902, or after that,
I would still be hopeful that the problem can be solved for it is quite
probable that the original plan of the building as a Post Hospital can be
found. If so, I am sure that the rooms would be small, about the size of
those shown in the plans of the apartments as they are today. Then there
was one 12-bed ward on the south-side as shown in the plans. That was for
enlisted men and was probably not altered.

Now, can you arrange with the Commanding Officer to have Master Sergeant
W. A. Fields see if the date can not be found to show when the second floor
was changed from its original plans to those of the General Hospital?
Also try to find the original plans of the Post Hospital. The General
Hospital probably started during the Spanish American War or soon after.
But the large rooms shown in the plans we have may not have been necessary
for several years.

Unless we unearth something to solve this discrepancy between my memory
and the plans, I cannot, of course, make any positive statement as to the
exact location of Reed's room. I thought we had found the room, but
evidently not if those walls are not the original ones. Somewhere in the
Post an answer can, I think, be found. Possibly as the building is so
small and may not be permanent, we had better just put a placque on the
building and forget the room. At any rate, the room as it was, evidently
does not exist today if the building was actually altered according to
plans.
